name: Milan
fun_fact: Fun fact: Milan is the birthplace of the Negroni Sbagliato ('wrong Negroni'), invented by mistake in 1972 when bartender Mirko Stocchetto accidentally grabbed sparkling wine instead of gin. The city is also Italy's largest rice producer, perfecting risotto alla Milanese!

hero_dishes.name: Risotto alla Milanese
hero_dishes.description: Luxuriously creamy saffron-perfumed risotto made with bone marrow and cheese. The signature golden color comes from precious saffron threads.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Legend says this dish originated in the 16th century when an apprentice working on the Duomo's stained-glass windows added saffron to white rice. Milan sits in the Po Valley, Italy's largest rice-producing region.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: RatanÃ  in Porta Nuova (famed for their version); Trattoria Milanese on Via Santa Marta for classic old-school preparation; MonzÃ¹ Bistrot for contemporary seafood risotto

hero_dishes.name: Ossobuco with Risotto
hero_dishes.description: Rich, slow-cooked veal shank braised until fall-off-the-bone tender, traditionally served alongside saffron risotto Milanese.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A classic Milanese pairing that showcases the region's expertise with both rice and veal, representing the city's culinary heritage.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: RatanÃ  for particularly rich ossobuco with historic fine-dining experience; Al Garghet (Via Selvanesco 36) for quality traditional preparation in rustic countryside setting; MonzÃ¹ Bistrot for tender slow-cooked version

hero_dishes.name: Cotoletta alla Milanese
hero_dishes.description: Breaded veal cutlet, golden and crispy, pounded thin and fried to perfection. A Milanese staple found at every traditional trattoria.
hero_dishes.origin_story: One of Milan's most iconic dishes, the cotoletta represents the city's love of simple but perfectly executed classics.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Al Garghet for traditional preparation; Trattoria Milanese for old-school versions; Osteria La Piola for classic trattoria style

signature_drinks.name: Negroni Sbagliato
signature_drinks.description: Equal parts Campari, sweet red vermouth, and sparkling wine (Prosecco) instead of gin. Served with orange slice and famously large ice cube.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Invented and still served at Bar Basso, the historic birthplace (over 500 cocktails on menu). Enjoy during aperitivo around 7pm at bars throughout Milan, especially in Navigli canal district

signature_drinks.name: Classic Aperitivo
signature_drinks.description: Milan is the godfather of Italian aperitivo culture. Negroni (gin, vermouth, Campari) and Spritz are standards, paired with complimentary food spreads.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Aperitivo culture starts at 7pm - the drink costs â‚¬6-15 and includes meats, cheeses, vegetables, breads. Head to Osteria Alla Concorrenza for natural wines; Madama Hostel & Bistrot for cocktails; Navigli canals for open-air patios

signature_drinks.name: Franciacorta Sparkling Wine
signature_drinks.description: Lombardy's answer to Champagne - high-quality sparkling wine from just outside Milan, often served during aperitivo.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Popular choice at Milan's aperitivo bars and enoteche, representing regional pride in Lombard wine production
